member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetActivityTask operation. Used by workers to retrieve a task (with the specified activity ARN) scheduled for execution by a running state machine. This initiates a long poll, where the service holds the HTTP connection open and responds as soon as a task becomes available (i.e. an execution of a task of this type is needed.) The maximum time the service holds on to the request before responding is 60 seconds. If no task is available within 60 seconds, the poll will return an empty result, that is, the taskToken returned is an empty string.
Workers should set their client side socket timeout to at least 65 seconds (5 seconds higher than the maximum time the service may hold the poll request).

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest.ActivityArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ActivityArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the activity to retrieve tasks from.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest.WorkerName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkerName.
An arbitrary name may be provided in order to identify the worker that the task is assigned to. This name will be used when it is logged in the execution history.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the GetActivityTask operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskResponse.Input
member.summary:

The JSON input data for the task.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskResponse.TaskToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TaskToken.
A token that identifies the scheduled task. This token must be copied and included in subsequent calls to SendTaskHeartbeat, SendTaskSuccess or SendTaskFailure in order to report the progress or completion of the task.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the GetExecutionHistory operation. Returns the history of the specified execution as a list of events. By default, the results are returned in ascending order of the timeStamp of the events. Use the reverseOrder parameter to get the latest events first. The results may be split into multiple pages. To retrieve subsequent pages, make the call again using the nextToken returned by the previous call.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.ExecutionArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
The maximum number of results that will be returned per call. nextToken can be used to obtain further pages of results. The default is 100 and the maximum allowed page size is 1000.
This is an upper limit only; the actual number of results returned per call may be fewer than the specified maximum.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
If a nextToken was returned by a previous call, there are more results available. To retrieve the next page of results, make the call again using the returned token in nextToken. Keep all other arguments unchanged.
The configured maxResults determines how many results can be returned in a single call.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetExecutionHistoryRequest.ReverseOrder
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ReverseOrder.
Lists events in descending order of their timeStamp.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskFailureRequest.TaskToken
member.summary:

The token that represents this task. Task tokens are generated by the service when the tasks are assigned to a worker (see GetActivityTask::taskToken).

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskFailureResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the SendTaskFailure operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the SendTaskHeartbeat operation. Used by workers to report to the service that the task represented by the specified taskToken is still making progress. This action resets the Heartbeat clock. The Heartbeat threshold is specified in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition. This action does not in itself create an event in the execution history. However, if the task times out, the execution history will contain an ActivityTimedOut event.
The Timeout of a task, defined in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition, is its maximum allowed duration, regardless of the number of SendTaskHeartbeat requests received.
This operation is only useful for long-lived tasks to report the liveliness of the task.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest.TaskToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TaskToken.
The token that represents this task. Task tokens are generated by the service when the tasks are assigned to a worker (see GetActivityTask::taskToken).

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the SendTaskHeartbeat operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskSuccessRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the SendTaskSuccess operation. Used by workers to report that the task identified by the taskToken completed successfully.

member.name: P:Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskSuccessRequest.Output

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsRequest
member.summary: Base class for StepFunctions operation requests.

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing StepFunctions
AWS Step Functions
AWS Step Functions is a web service that enables you to coordinate the components of distributed applications and microservices using visual workflows. You build applications from individual components that each perform a discrete function, or task, allowing you to scale and change applications quickly. Step Functions provides a graphical console to visualize the components of your application as a series of steps. It automatically triggers and tracks each step, and retries when there are errors, so your application executes in order and as expected, every time. Step Functions logs the state of each step, so when things do go wrong, you can diagnose and debug problems quickly.
Step Functions manages the operations and underlying infrastructure for you to ensure your application is available at any scale. You can run tasks on the AWS cloud, on your own servers, or an any system that has access to AWS. Step Functions can be accessed and used with the Step Functions console, the AWS SDKs (included with your Beta release invitation email), or an HTTP API (the subject of this document).

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonStepFunctionsClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.GetActivityTask(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.GetActivityTaskRequest)
member.summary:
Used by workers to retrieve a task (with the specified activity ARN) scheduled for execution by a running state machine. This initiates a long poll, where the service holds the HTTP connection open and responds as soon as a task becomes available (i.e. an execution of a task of this type is needed.) The maximum time the service holds on to the request before responding is 60 seconds. If no task is available within 60 seconds, the poll will return an empty result, that is, the taskToken returned is an empty string.
Workers should set their client side socket timeout to at least 65 seconds (5 seconds higher than the maximum time the service may hold the poll request).
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the GetActivityTask service method.
member.returns: The response from the GetActivityTask service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The specified activity does not exist.
The maximum number of workers concurrently polling for activity tasks has been reached.
The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for GetActivityTask Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.AmazonStepFunctionsClient.SendTaskHeartbeat(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest)
member.summary:
Used by workers to report to the service that the task represented by the specified taskToken is still making progress. This action resets the Heartbeat clock. The Heartbeat threshold is specified in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition. This action does not in itself create an event in the execution history. However, if the task times out, the execution history will contain an ActivityTimedOut event.
The Timeout of a task, defined in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition, is its maximum allowed duration, regardless of the number of SendTaskHeartbeat requests received.
This operation is only useful for long-lived tasks to report the liveliness of the task.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the SendTaskHeartbeat service method.
member.returns: The response from the SendTaskHeartbeat service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The provided token is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for SendTaskHeartbeat Operation

member.name: T:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions
member.summary:
Interface for accessing StepFunctions
AWS Step Functions
AWS Step Functions is a web service that enables you to coordinate the components of distributed applications and microservices using visual workflows. You build applications from individual components that each perform a discrete function, or task, allowing you to scale and change applications quickly. Step Functions provides a graphical console to visualize the components of your application as a series of steps. It automatically triggers and tracks each step, and retries when there are errors, so your application executes in order and as expected, every time. Step Functions logs the state of each step, so when things do go wrong, you can diagnose and debug problems quickly.
Step Functions manages the operations and underlying infrastructure for you to ensure your application is available at any scale. You can run tasks on the AWS cloud, on your own servers, or an any system that has access to AWS. Step Functions can be accessed and used with the Step Functions console, the AWS SDKs (included with your Beta release invitation email), or an HTTP API (the subject of this document).

member.name: M:Amazon.StepFunctions.IAmazonStepFunctions.SendTaskHeartbeat(Amazon.StepFunctions.Model.SendTaskHeartbeatRequest)
member.summary:
Used by workers to report to the service that the task represented by the specified taskToken is still making progress. This action resets the Heartbeat clock. The Heartbeat threshold is specified in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition. This action does not in itself create an event in the execution history. However, if the task times out, the execution history will contain an ActivityTimedOut event.
The Timeout of a task, defined in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition, is its maximum allowed duration, regardless of the number of SendTaskHeartbeat requests received.
This operation is only useful for long-lived tasks to report the liveliness of the task.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the SendTaskHeartbeat service method.
member.returns: The response from the SendTaskHeartbeat service method, as returned by StepFunctions.
member.exception: The provided token is invalid.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for SendTaskHeartbeat Operation
